messageBody:
## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-08-30T16:23:54Z
## Message ID: 20210830-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2021-08-30T05:20Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are likely caused by a weak coronal hole high speed stream which arrived on 2021-08-29, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 441 km/s. The solar wind speed observed at L1 is currently around 400 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-08-30T05:20:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-08-28T12:12:52Z
## Message ID: 20210828-AL-003
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2021-08-28T02:05Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the combined arrival of CME with ID 2021-08-23T06:36:00-CME-001 and corresponding IPS with ID 2021-08-27T00:25:00-IPS-001 and CME with ID 2021-08-24T13:25:00-CME-001 and corresponding IPS with ID 2021-08-27T11:42:00-IPS-001 (see notifications 20210826-AL-001, 20210826-AL-002, 20210827-AL-001).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-08-28T02:05:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (ensemble) (Parker Solar Probe, STEREO A, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-08-28T02:54:14Z
## Message ID: 20210828-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2021-08-26T18:53:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20210827-AL-002). 

Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A and STEREO B. For 48 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2021-08-28T16:17Z and 2021-08-29T14:51Z (average arrival 2021-08-29T03:34Z) for 85% of simulations.
- STEREO B between about 2021-08-29T11:26Z and 2021-08-29T20:35Z (average arrival 2021-08-29T16:29Z) for 14% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2021-08-28T23:30Z and 2021-08-30T05:58Z (average arrival 2021-08-29T13:20Z) for 95% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 66% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-5 range (below minor to minor).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-08-27_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX089/20210826_185300_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX089_anim_tim-den.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-08-27_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX089/20210826_185300_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX089_arrival_Earth.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-08-27_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX089/20210826_185300_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX089_Earth_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-08-27_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX089/20210826_185300_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX089_probabilistic_Kp_forecast_wdist.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-08-27_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX089/20210826_185300_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX089_arrival_STA.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-08-27_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX089/20210826_185300_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX089_STA_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-08-27_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX089/20210826_185300_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX089_arrival_STB.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-08-27_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX089/20210826_185300_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX089_STB_stack.gif

## Notes:
Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-08-27_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX089/Detailed_results_20210826_185300_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX089.txt

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Parker Solar Probe, STEREO A, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-08-27T19:57:48Z
## Message ID: 20210827-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2021-08-26T18:53Z.

Estimated speed: ~599 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 45 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -20/12 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2021-08-26T18:53:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Parker Solar Probe and STEREO A.  The leading edge of the CME will reach Parker Solar Probe at 2021-08-28T05:14Z and STEREO A at 2021-08-29T08:42Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2021-08-29T18:51Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 4-5 (below minor to minor).
   
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2021-08-26T18:53:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210827_003600_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210827_003600_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210827_003600_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210827_003600_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210827_003600_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210827_003600_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_PSP_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210827_003600_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

This CME event (2021-08-26T18:53:00-CME-001) is associated with C3.0 flare with ID 2021-08-26T17:48:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2021-08-26T18:18Z. 

SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Interplanetary Shock
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-08-27T17:49:40Z
## Message ID: 20210827-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significant interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR at L1 at 2021-08-27T11:42Z. 

The shock is caused by CME with ID 2021-08-24T13:25:00-CME-001 (see notification 20210826-AL-002). Geomagnetic storm may be expected.

Activity ID: 2021-08-27T11:42:00-IPS-001.

## Notes: 
This signature was preceded by the arrival of CME with ID 2021-08-23T06:36:00-CME-001 on 2021-08-27T00:25Z. This event is still under analysis.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Correction to Space Weather Notification - CME (Parker Solar Probe, STEREO A, Solar Orbiter, Missions Near Earth)
##

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

S-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2021-08-24T13:25Z.

Estimated speed: ~454 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 33 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -36/8 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2021-08-24T13:25:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Parker Solar Probe, STEREO A (minor impact), and Solar Orbiter (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME will reach Parker Solar Probe at 2021-08-26T04:52Z, STEREO A at 2021-08-27T18:00Z, and Solar Orbiter at 2021-08-26T20:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2021-08-28T03:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 
   
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2021-08-24T13:25:00-CME-001):

## Notes: 

This CME event (2021-08-24T13:25:00-CME-001) is associated with B8.8 flare with ID 2021-08-24T12:03:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2021-08-24T12:16Z.


SCORE CME typification system:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Parker Solar Probe, STEREO A, Solar Orbiter, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-08-26T15:57:25Z

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

S-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2021-08-24T13:25Z.

Estimated speed: ~454 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 33 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -36/8 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2021-08-24T13:25:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Parker Solar Probe, STEREO A (minor impact), and Solar Orbiter (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME will reach Parker Solar Probe at 2021-08-26T04:52Z, STEREO A at 2021-05-27T18:00Z, and Solar Orbiter at 2021-08-26T20:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME might have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2021-05-28T03:00Z (plus minus 7 hours).  

Please note that this analysis is very approximate as it is based on limited coronagraph data (LASCO only) and on the location of the eruption in SDO AIA and STEREO A EUVI imagery.
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME 2021-08-24T13:25:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210824_205700_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif

## Notes: 
This CME event (2021-08-24T13:25:00-CME-001) is associated with B8.8 flare with ID 2021-08-24T12:03:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2021-08-24T12:16Z.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 18, 2021 - August 24, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-08-25T20:06:14Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-08-18T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-08-24T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210825-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below). Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at the NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible by SOHO LASCO C2 on 2021-08-19T23:12Z would have a minor impact at Mars at 2021-08-25T14:00Z and a glancing blow to Solar Orbiter at 2021-08-22T09:00Z (plus/minus 7 hours). It was also predicted that the C-type CME first visible by SOHO LASCO C2 on 2021-08-20T06:12Z would have a minor impact at Mars at 2021-08-24T19:00Z, a glancing blow to Solar Orbiter at 2021-08-22T08:00Z, and reach OSIRIS-REx at 2021-08-23T15:00Z (plus/minus 7 hours) (see notification 20210820-AL-001). 

Geomagnetic activity was below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2021-08-19T23:12Z     ~560            C              -133/6                 24                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2021-08-20T06:12Z     ~986            C              -136/-22               29                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-08-25T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-08-31T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels for the upcoming week. There are two active regions 12859 and 12860 visible on the Earth-facing disk. Active region 12859 has produced some low level C-class flaring during the second half of the reporting period and could continue to produce B and C-class flares throughout the outlook period. Active region 12860 developed overnight on 2021-08-24 and may produce B and C-class flares throughout the outlook period. There are three unnumbered active regions visible in STEREO A EUVI 195.  The two active regions further east in the STEREO A imagery may rotate onto the Earth-facing disk starting around 2021-08-26.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels for the upcoming week due to the anticipated Earth arrival of the S-type CME first seen by SOHO LASCO C2 on 2021-08-23T06:36Z and the expected arrival of multiple coronal hole high speed streams visible at disk center around 2021-08-21 and 2021-08-23, respectively.  Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at the NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the S-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 on 2021-08-23T06:36Z would impact missions near Earth on 2021-08-26T20:25Z with max Kp estimates between 2-4 and additional anticipated impacts to Parker Solar Probe at 2021-08-25T05:05Z, STEREO A at 2021-08-27T00:00Z, and STEREO B at 2021-08-27T02:00Z (plus/minus 7 hours).  There are two separate coronal holes that crossed the central meridian of the Earth-facing disk on 2021-08-23 that may simultaneously become geoeffective on 2021-08-30.  The anticipated high speed stream from the coronal hole visible at disk center on 2021-08-21 may have been detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 late on 2021-08-24.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Mars, OSIRIS-REx, Solar Orbiter)
##

## Message ID: 20210820-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2021-08-20T06:12Z.

Estimated speed: ~986 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 29 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -136/-22 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2021-08-20T06:12:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Mars (minor impact), OSIRIS-REx (glancing blow), and Solar Orbiter (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME will reach Mars at 2021-08-24T19:00Z, OSIRIS-REx at 2021-08-23T15:00Z, and Solar Orbiter at 2021-08-22T08:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2021-08-20T06:12:00-CME-001):

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 11, 2021 - August 17, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-08-18T21:07:34Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-08-11T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-08-17T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210818-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2021-08-12T09:36Z     ~524            C               159/-10               25                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2021-08-12T21:48Z     ~532            C              -145/-14               12                          SOHO, STEREO A                     

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-08-18T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-08-24T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to minor for the upcoming week. There are three numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk (12853, 12855, and 12857) that have been decaying in the past few days. Two or more unnumbered active regions currently visible on the eastern limb in STEREO A EUV imagery may rotate onto the Earth-facing disk around 2021-08-21. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be at low to minor levels during the outlook period. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES has been at somewhat elevated levels since 2021-08-17 due to the high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-08-15 and might become further enhanced. A small network of equatorial coronal holes that crossed the central meridian of the Earth-facing disk around 2021-08-16 might possibly become geoeffective around 2021-08-21.    

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 04, 2021 - August 10, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-08-11T20:45:58Z

## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-08-10T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210811-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs during this reporting period.    

Geomagnetic activity was at low levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period. 

STEREO A IMPACT detected a possible arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2021-08-05. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period on 2021-08-04 (see notifications 20210804-AL-001 and 20210804-AL-002). These significantly elevated electron flux levels were associated with the arrival of a CME on 2021-08-02 that was first visible by SOHO LASCO C2 imagery on 2021-07-29T00:24Z.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to minor this week due to elevated energetic electron fluxes on the Earth's outer radiation belt, and the arrival of the high speed stream at STEREO A described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-08-11T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-08-17T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. There are five active regions on the Earth-facing disk (12851, 12852, 12853, 12854, and 12855) visible in the available EUV imagery from SDO and STEREO A. Three of these active regions have decayed into plagues (12851, 12852, and 12853) while the other two (12854 and 12855) were numbered as of 2021-08-11. The decayed active regions 12851 and 12852 will rotate off of the Earth-facing disk early in the outlook period, along with newly numbered active region 12854. The region of 12853 produced one C-class flare starting on 2021-08-08. One unnumbered active region is visible in STEREO A EUVI 195 that may rotate onto the Earth-facing disk around 2021-08-12.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A northern extension of the southern pole coronal hole crossed the central meridian of the Earth-facing disk on 2021-08-08 and may become geoeffective around late 2021-08-12.

## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at minor level during this reporting period.  There was one C-type CME (see details below). 

Geomagnetic activity was at low to minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The maximum Kp index level of 5 was reached during the synoptic period 2021-08-02T18:00Z-21:00Z. This elevated value of Kp was caused by an S-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 on 2021-07-29T00:24Z. The predicted arrival of this CME was detected at L1 by DSCOVR/ACE at 2021-08-02T09:03Z (see notification 20210802-AL-001).

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-08-04T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-08-10T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to minor for the upcoming week. There are two unnumbered active regions and one numbered Active Region 12850 on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 12850 is expected to rotate beyond the western limb by 2021-08-08. One or more unnumbered active regions are currently visible on the eastern limb in STEREO A EUV imagery and may rotate onto the Earth-facing disk around 2021-08-07. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between minor and low levels during the outlook period. The >2.0 MeV energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2021-08-04T16:00Z (see notifications 20210804-AL-001 and 20210804-AL-002) due to the above mentioned arrival of an S-type CME at L1 on 2021-08-02 (see notification 20210802-AL-001) and could remain elevated during the beginning of the outlook period. An equatorial coronal hole and the southern extension of a north pole coronal hole that both crossed the central meridian of the Earth-facing disk on 2021-08-03 (as seen in the available SDO EUV imagery) may become geoeffective around 2021-08-07.

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2021-08-04T16:00Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the CME with ID 2021-07-29T00:24:00-CME-001, which arrived at L1 at 2021-08-02T09:03Z (see notification 20210802-AL-001).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-08-04T16:00:00-RBE-001.
